citation.article-title: Numerical and chemical classification of Actinoplanes and some related actinomycetes

p.s: Description of Actinoplanes humidus sp. nov.
Actinoplanes humidus (hu'mi.dus. L adj. umidus, wet, damp, moist)
Light to yellow-orange brown substrate mycelium formed on modified Bennett's agar and a dark diffusible pigment on Bacto Tryptic Soy agar supplemented with RNA.
Sporangia spherical and abundant, spores motile and formed irregularly within sporangia.

Degrades arbutin, casein, DNA, elastin, lecithin, pectin, RNA, starch and tyrosine; utilizes D- and L-arabinose, dextrin, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, D-lactose, D-maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, methyl β-D-glucoside, D-sorbitol, D-xylose, p-hydroxybenzoic acid, sodium fumarate and sodium succinate as sole carbon sources but not D-cellobiose, erythritol, meso-inositol, catechol, coumarin, m- and o-hydroxybenzoic acid, syringaldehyde, syringic acid or vanillin.
The organism is tolerant to a range of antibiotics and chemical inhibitors (Table 6).
It grows at 4 and 30 °C, but not at 37 °C.
The peptidoglycan contains meso- and hydroxydiaminopimelic acid.
The principal wall sugars are arabinose, galactose, mannose and xylose.

The organism also contains complex mixtures of straight- and branched-chain fatty acids, with some straight-chain components predominating, tetrahydrogenated menaquinones with nine isoprene units as the predominant isoprenologue, and major amounts of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylinositol and two uncharacterized glycolipids.
Type strain : Actinoplanes humidus LA6 (IFO 1491 5 , NCIB 20000).
